title: How does one differentiate between narcissism and self confidence? - Quora

response.answer_text: Narcissistic Personality Disorder and many of the traits associated with it are actually defenses against underlying low or unstable self-esteem. This is the opposite of true self-confidence. One of the reasons for the confusion is that people with Exhibitionist Narcissistic Personality Disorder appear very self-confident and want other people to see them as perfect. Here are some ways that can you distinguish true self-confidence from Narcissistic defensive grandiosity. People with the Exhibitionist version of NPD: Make extreme and unrealistic claims about themselves, such as, “I am perfect” or “I am never wrong.”Try to impress other people by name-dropping or bragging about their successes.Will not apologize when they are wrong.Feel entitled to special treatment or act as if the rules do not apply to them.Need to be the center of admiring attention.Cannot take negative feedback gracefully.Lack emotional empathy.Devalue other people.Have no real interest in other people and either tune out when other people are speaking or jump in and dominate the conversation.Shift the blame for their failures to other people.People who are truly self-confident: Do not claim to be perfect.Can apologize.Can let other people enjoy the spotlight occasionally.Are interested in what other people have to say.Have emotional empathy.Can take a reasonable amount of criticism.Do not usually devalue other people.Do not expect special treatment.Punchline: Being “Narcissistic” is a defense against feeling ashamed and inadequate. It was developed during childhood and now is habitual. True self-confidence is robust because it is developed by overcoming obstacles. It continues developing in adulthood as the person faces new challenges. A2A Elinor Greenberg, PhD, CGP In private practice in NYC and the author of the book: Borderline, Narcissistic, and Schizoid Adaptations. www.elinorgreenberg.com

“Narcissistic” could apply to traits almost anywhere on the continuum of behaviors associated with Narcissistic Personality Disorder. Some narcissism is normal, as an evolutionary survival trait, and an excess is a mental disorder. What differentiates self-confidence and NPD is that an underlying element of NPD is a feeling of inferiority. https://www.quora.com/I-am-not-confident-enough-to-take-on-a-leadership-role-and-this-hinders-my-career-growth-What-can-I-do-to-overcome-this-fear-and-get-ready/answer/Dan-Robb-2 tl;dr: Self-esteem/self-confidence is based on competence (as opposed to ignorance and/or narcissistic bravado; with competence being based on proper preparation [i.e., education, training, and practice], with such preparation leading to productivity [i.e., accomplishment]); which, in conjunction with a positive attitude, will allow one to succeed even if faced with temporary failure. Such nurtured competence will in all probability lead to a life worth living. Confidence includes being able to question one’s perspectives based on continued research and newly acquired information. This is known as the concept of defensive pessimism, which should be employed to anticipate problems, and facilitate the use self-doubt to motivate effective action. https://www.quora.com/Why-do-you-think-some-people-need-to-make-themselves-feel-better-by-making-you-seem-inferior/answer/Dan-Robb-2 tl;dr: Self-confidence not based on competence, or based on an exaggerated sense of self-worth (i.e., arrogance), can indicate some level of narcissism; which can incorporate insecurity. Narcissistic Personality Disorder is diagnosed in those having a majority of these traits: Self-importance (e.g., exaggerated achievements); preoccupation with fantasies of unlimited success, power, brilliance, etc.; belief they are special; requiring admiration; a sense of entitlement; exploitative of others; lacking in empathy; envy; and arrogance. And they are often paranoid, and invariably have an inferiority complex. References: Kulbarsh, P. (2008, April 21). The malignant narcissist. Retrieved from: http://www.officer.com/article/10248968/the-malignant-narcissist?page=2 Ressert, S. (2017, December 17). Narcissistic Personality Disorder. Retrieved from: http://www.officer.com/article/10248968/the-malignant-narcissist?page=2

Narcissists (someone with npd) view things in an inflexible black and white way. They have a disorder wherein they lack an integrated sense of self, instead viewing themselves and others as “all good” or “all bad.” Since a person viewing themselves as “all bad” is not a viable alternative, narcissists project their faults onto others, which accounts for their behaviors such as Criticizing and blaming others (projection)Gaslighting (“That’s your perception)Other behaviors to offload shame (deny, distort, etc.)Since they must view themselves in an unnatural and unrealistic “all good” way, they are constrained to manipulate others to share their view of themselves. Theirs is a lifestyle which involves ubiquitous manipulation and abuse, as the techniques narcissists use to control others constitute abuse; they’re psychologically very damaging. It is in this context that narcissists are self confident. They are striving to make a favorable impression, and manipulate the other person to enter into their view of themselves, which is their core value in life. Clearly a person can be self confident without being a narcissist. Nothing more needs to be said on this side of the question. To summarize, being self confident is a symptom a narcissist is likely to have, where the personality has been sketched to some extent above, showing such narcissism involves much more than merely being self confident.

What is the difference between being narcissistic and being self confident? On the surface the two may resemble each other but in reality there a BIG DIFFERENCE. To the point of being direct opposites. A self confident person: 1- Knows their self worth 2- Respects the healthy boundaries of others.. 3- Asks for what they want directly 4- Can be told “no” without sulking or taking it personally. 5- Lives by the rule: Do unto others what you would have them do unto you. 6- Is emotionally a mature adult. 7- Is unafraid of having imperfections. Knows they have strengths and weaknesses. A narcissist, on the other hand; 1- Derives their sense of self worth from the look of admiration they see in the eyes of others. 2- Does not understand the concept of other people’s boundaries. Is motivated by their needs when it comes to others. 3- Manipulates to reach their goals. 4- doesn’t take no for an answer. Will always try to turn a “no” into a “yes” 5- Uses extreme double standards (they can cheat, lie, deceive and are justified) while their partner is held to gold standards of sainthood. 6- Is emotionally a 5 year old in the body of a mature adult.. 7- Projects a fake image of perfection they try to protect at all cost. Thanks for A2A.

There is self confidence in narcissism, but if it is of a pronounced, pathological sort, we ordinarily ascribe it to being a part of the False Self, which is a protective cover for a more comprehensive understanding of the individual. What is referred to as “healthy narcissism,” may relate to self confidence, because there an individuated Self from other to begin with. In pathological narcissism, the other is experienced as an extension of the person, not a separate other, as Big O Other. Self confidence can come from an individuated Self, or one that has little differentiation, and is counterfeit, in that is contingent upon having other selfobjects as mirrors to maintain the narcissistic person’s fragile Self structure. We see this with people that need others to be, “ Yes People, “ who don’t challenge them with “real” accurate feedback, but are always supporting the narcissistic person’s Ideal Self, which is synonymous with the development of the False Self. These are usually is constituted by strivings for mirroring and acknowledging of grandiose and/or omnipotent needs, and fantasies of wealth, power, beauty, abilities, talents, etc. But what it lacks, is a tolerance for recognizing the ordinary, of having clay feet, being sometimes wrong, not being paid attention to, not having others think you are so special. That leads to a fracturing of the False Self, and the rotten, stinking guts are seen by the world, which results in intolerable shame and a real loss of self esteem and confidence which was illusory to begin with. Mirror, mirror, on the wall, whose the fairest of them all ? Well, of course you are, and so pure like driven snow. Bruce Kugler
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Hollie Black Ramsey

response.answer_text: It’s not a thin line. On the contrary, it’s a wide gap. How wide? Maybe as the Grand Canyon. True confidence has nothing to do with narcissist’s inflated ego. The first one is genuine and is build on a stable foundation, being an integral part of ones personality. On the other hand, narcissist’s inflated ego or as they call it “the false self” is like a soap bubble. It might be huge and colorful, but it will burst as soon as you “touch” it. That’s how strong and stable it is. While narcissists may appear as extremely confident and full of self, deep inside they are small children. In order to maintain their inflated ego, they need constant narcissistic supply in the form of adulation, admiration, praise and external validation. Self-confident people don’t need the approval of others. They know who they are and they get their sens of self-worth from within.

N PD doesn't care if there late Self confident does and shows it. Npd doesn t ask questions about your day. They don't care. Self confident does because they want to be part of it. Npd competes with you resents your talents Self confident encourages you to be your best and then brags they know you Npd encourages you to share your deepest fears or secrets by making you feel like your the best thing that's ever happen to them and then shares all of it with everyone else making you look weak or trashy. Self confident doesn t say much shows how they feel and you naturally share your fears and secrets and then they help you over come them Npd will hate your confidence and make sure when they're done with you you won t have any!!!

A narcissist deep down has zero confidence,but they will portray the total opposite to the public .They easy way to tell the difference is how easily swayed they are to opinion.Someone who is self confident usually has an opinion on whatever subject and will usually stick to their beliefs no matter what .On the other hand a narcissist will swing their beliefs to the majority in order to feel accepted.They are not open to criticism in any fashion at all!! Which means they are not confident in themselves if they can’t take a comment.Someone who is confident will frankly not care in anyway if they are criticized .

A great deal, indeed. he main difference is that a self-confident person actually has a real good feeling about himself and is more or less satisfied with what he sees he knows his weaknesses and strengths and he is able to have a self-esteem. A confident person loves himself. A narcisstic person has a very low self-esteem, he only puts on a show to seem self-confident and he is hurtful towards other people, trying to pull others down by criticising them to make himself feel better and to come out better and that boosts his ego and makes him feel as if he had self-confidence but he has not. The fact that he is haughty does not equal to self-confidence. A narcisstic person does not love himself even if he seems to demonstrate that.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Hollie Black Ramsey

response.answer_text: Confidence is simply true self-worth, built from curiosity, learning and awareness. To engage in the process that builds confidence one has to be grounded in a positive self-image. Someone who isn't walking around with a good self-image of themselves and builds tools to help themselves interact with the world will build tools to ease their lack of self-worthiness. These are narcissistic tools to shield their fragile self-image. The difference is simply how each sees himself (or herself).
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Hollie Black Ramsey

response.answer_text: When I met my ‘ex’ NPD husband (he was 21), he was the most ‘confident’ person I had ever met (I was 27) and even though I wasn’t thrilled about our age difference he acted very mature for his age. As time went on (now I am able to see this in 20/20 hindsight after being married for 23 years) he was gradually morphing into the full blown Narcissist that he is today. He turned from ‘confident’ to ‘annoyingly arrogant’ and he also got more and more immature as time went on. If I had to guess this is probably how it starts out for people with NPD and then at some point as they age, they turn into an ‘over the top arrogant Narcissist’ .
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Hollie Black Ramsey

response.answer_text: There is no thin line — either you have NPD or you don’t and if you do have it, you are most assuredly not self-confident. To say that self-confidence and NPD are closely related is, at best, a glib way of interpreting a very debilitating and troubling mental disorder. To be clear, people with NPD are not confident — quite the opposite. They are haunted by insecurities. Furthermore, NPD is predicated on having a very traumatic childhood coupled with a particular temperament that an individual is born with. In addition, someone with NPD has very specific, verifiable symptoms — including grandiosity (read: not self-confidence) — that can be diagnosed by a certified mental health professional. I’ll repeat: there is no thin line between narcissism and self-confidence. However, there is a very wide chasm between the two.

Narcissists actually, underneath it all, lack REAL confidence, or they wouldn’t have to constantly promote themselves so shamelessly, as _______does, but we won’t use names here. Narcissism is a personality disorder, not to be confused with simple (and common) self-aggrandizement. Narcissism require that the disordered person to constantly seek the adulation, praise, amazement, support agreement of others to shore up their likely poor self-image. Their APPEARANCE is of someone who thinks of themselves as vastly superior, but this is quickly abandoned when their great need for acknowledgement is revealed. No truly confident person needs such constant vindication or approval because they already have that within themselves.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Hollie Black Ramsey

response.answer_text: There is a HUGE difference in being self confident and a true narcissist. A narcissist does not show emotions, they gaslight, they use and mentally abuse everyone they know. Their brains are wired differently. Lots of people used to say a narcissist was someone who constantly looks in the mirror or someone just plain conceited. We all need self confidence to to carry on with life and what it thows our way.

I can only say that I thought I was some what confident.till I was with my narcissist partner.and over two years she sucked that from me as well as many other things.I think the person with a toxic disease.has the upper hand when it comes to this matter.they are like a magician.the sleight of hand, the smoke screens.and of course the lies.and by all means don't forget the cheating. I am still trying to get to where I once was before this person turned my world upside down.but when I was what Most would call confident. I believed in morals and values.when I am with someone, whether the relationship was good or bad.would never lie, steal or cheat!!!to me there is no comparison…..

It's a completely apples to oranges comparison. Confidence wouldn't make you want to hurt someone emotionally just because it makes you feel better. In fact in some ways, perhaps, narcissists are the opposite of confident, in that they constantly need to manipulate and hurt others to feel “better than". They are empty souls, they are emotional vampires. A confident person is going to be confident with or without an audience, constant approval or adulation. They may enjoy those things, but coercing them out of people they siphon for attention is a completely alien thing to a normally confident person.

One is selfish pursuit of ones desires not caring how it affects others. One is feeling entitled to more than every one else. One is pretending to be self confident but being ate up with self doubt. One is needing to be feed praise and and adoration to build themself up. On is based on false projections onto a mask not representative of their true self. The other? Not so much.

Having self confidence doesn’t hurt anyone else. It is a strong positive Feeling of trust in ones abilities, qualities and judgement. It’s actuLly a good thing. It’s what keeps us from cowering in a corner instead of trying new things. Narcissism is having an over inflated feeling of self worth. You are a special human and nobody else could possibly understand you. Therefore you belong at the center of everyone’s world. HUGE DIFFERENCE!
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Hollie Black Ramsey

response.answer_text: Narcissists must be validated by others. They can not regulate their own self worth and self esteem. They must have feedback to refer to, and they can’t provide it for themselves. Someone that is truly self confident doesn’t need anyone else’s validation to feel confident in their identity. Self confidence, in this way, is the opposite of narcissism. People with self confidence gain validation from within themselves. Narcissists gain validation from outside of themselves.

Narcissistic are self-absorbed people whereas people with self-confidence feels secure from the inside out. Like for instance… They don’t feel the need to put others down to feel good about themselves.
Narcism is purely isolated in a narrow cage.. Confidence includes dealings with other people. A confident person has no need for servility from others.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Hollie Black Ramsey

response.answer_text: Narcissism is a psychological dysfunction viewing one’s self as being separate, paramount in contrast to everyone else. In other words, the actions and behaviors of the narcissistic self are different, superior than everyone else. The narcissist views laws governing public behavior of everyone do not apply to the narcissistic self.

Narcissism is the opposite of self-confidence , in fact, it's a defense mechanism to cover the complete lack of self-believe, by focusing entirely on one's self. Also a narcissist truly doesn't care about what other people feel or go through.

response.answer_text: The equivalent of being a vampire or a blood donor. Someone who is self-confident can give freely. A narcissistic person is continually seeking affirmation.
